I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
policy-based grant to Nauru for the Public Financial Management Reform Program.1 
 
2.  The program aims to support the government’s longer-term development objectives of 
improving the living standards of the people of Nauru through the government delivering more 
efficient and equitable social services. This two-tranche program grant totals $4 million. The 
first tranche of $2 million will be disbursed upon grant effectiveness as all first tranche policy 
actions have been accomplished. The second tranche of $2 million will be available after 
accomplishing the policy actions for the second tranche, projected to be achieved in 1 year.  
 
II.  THE PROGRAM 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Nauru faces many serious development challenges, with almost no private sector, no 
banking services, little arable land, limited fresh water supply, extremely high levels of debt, 
and inadequate sources of government revenue. Education outcomes are improving but are 
still poor by international standards and have contributed to high rates of youth unemployment. 
There are comparatively few experienced persons to take on key management roles in the 
public sector. Levels of noncommunicable diseases (i.e., diabetes and cancer) are among the 
highest in the world. There is an urgent need to improve health and education service delivery, 
set standards and targets, and measure progress. A healthy and better educated population 
will be able to take greater advantage of job opportunities locally and abroad. That Nauru has 
been invited to join Australia’s2 and New Zealand’s seasonal worker schemes could have a 
positive effect on household incomes and the standard of living of the population at large. 
 
4.  Nauru  remains  vulnerable  to  the  current  uncertainty  in  the  global  economy.  The 
government  generates  budget  revenues  from  (i)  dividends  and  returns  from  state-owned 
enterprises (SOEs), mainly from phosphate mining, processing, and export; (ii) customs duties; 
(iii) fishing license fees; (iv) petroleum sales; (v) other nontax revenues such as hotel taxes and 
airport charges; and (vi) budget support from development partners.3 Tax-based revenues are 
limited  due  to  the  country’s  narrow  economic  base.  Currently,  Nauru  has  no  legislation 
authorizing taxation of businesses or households. Tax revenues are limited to customs duties 
and excises. Nauru’s limited and volatile revenues, like fishing licenses and phosphate-related 
payments, continue to be difficult to forecast, and both are subject to forces beyond the control 
of the government. The country is highly dependent on external assistance to meet essential 
needs, with domestic revenue accounting for only 42% of total expenditure in FY 2011. 
 
5.  Since phosphate mining and exports are the domain of SOEs,4 the Nauruan economy is 
dominated by the public sector, which accounts for more than two-thirds of economic activity. 
Republic of Nauru Phosphate Corporation (RONPHOS), responsible for the processing and 
export of phosphate, has been unable to pay its projected dividends to the government and

was without a chief executive officer since 2008. The supply of electricity, water, and fuel was 
previously provided by the Nauru Phosphate Company and subsequently by the Nauru Utilities 
Authority  (NUA),  an  unincorporated  government  entity.  NUA’s  uncertain  legal  status  has 
hampered its ability to manage its staff resources effectively. Poor asset management has led 
to frequent power outages. NUA has also required large fuel subsidies. 
 
6.  Private sector activity is minimal. In addition to phosphate, other possible industries 
include  niche  tourism,  commercial  tuna  fishing,  and  the  manufacture  of  dolomite  tiles.5 
Australia, in a recent review of its development assistance, acknowledged that the growth 
prospects of Pacific microstates such as Nauru were limited. The review also prioritized plans 
to considerably increase development assistance to microstates to offset the lack of private 
sector activity.6 Much of this assistance is to be delivered through program-based approaches, 
which will require an improvement in these countries’ public financial management (PFM) 
capabilities.7 
 
7.  A recent Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) assessment, prepared 
under an Asian Development Bank (ADB) regional technical assistance (TA),8 identified several 
shortcomings of Nauru’s PFM system. Particular areas of concern are poor internal controls, an 
inadequate regulatory framework for procurements, and unsustainable debt levels.  
 
8.  The overall standard of internal controls is weak. Although expenditure controls are 
strong, other internal controls prescribed in the accounting and budget manual, last revised in 
1979, are weak and inconsistent with current practices. There are no financial regulations that 
govern internal controls. 
 
9.  The regulatory framework for procurements is not enforceable due to the lack of specific 
regulations. It is also deficient in defining procurement procedures for SOEs and government 
agencies, and does not define minimum requirements for competitive tenders, quotes, or other 
procurement processes. The framework is not transparent and lacks a complaints mechanism.  
 
10.  ADB categorizes Nauru at high risk of debt distress. Its external debt level is high at 
over 95% of gross domestic product. The overall level of indebtedness (including external and 
internal debt) has been reduced by 14% over the past 5 years to A$549.0 million, largely due to 
write-downs and debt relief. Internal debt amounts to A$480.7 million and external debt to 
A$68.8 million of the outstanding balance. 
 
11.  Nauru’s PFM system is still largely paper-based and makes use of Excel spreadsheets. 
This system adds considerable time and complexity to budgeting and increases the risk of 
budget overspending. Public finance, national accounts, and balance of payments statistics are 
either unavailable or out of date. 
 
12.  Nauru has large social and economic infrastructure needs, not least for a new port and 
a hospital. External funding for these projects will hinge on the preparation of a credible, 
budgeted, and prioritized strategic infrastructure development plan.  
 
13.  Nauru has no national women’s policy and until June 2011, had been one of the last

seven countries in the world not to ratify the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All 
Forms  of  Discrimination  against  Women  (CEDAW).  There  is  little  awareness  of  gender-
sensitive budgeting issues in Nauru and women are generally underrepresented in economic 
decision-making bodies. 
 
14.  To correct the above shortcomings, the government has embarked on a major PFM 
reform as expressed in a PFM action plan, prepared under ADB TA (footnote 8), and underpins 
this program. The proposed program will support the government’s efforts to (i) improve its 
fiscal performance, (ii) strengthen corporate governance and performance of key SOEs, and 
(iii) bolster the legal and policy framework for equitable access to social services. Efficient 
public financial and fiscal management will result in better development outcomes in Nauru, 
where dependence on official development assistance will persist in the medium-to-long term.  
 
15.  The program will strengthen public sector effectiveness, a priority under ADB’s Pacific 
Approach, 2010–2014.9 The program also supports implementing the National Sustainable 
Development  Strategy,10 which  emphasizes  sustainable  fiscal  management.  It  envisions 
establishment of a new trust fund, which ADB has assisted in the design of, to save some 
current revenues for future generations.11 The program was developed in consultation with the 
Australian Agency for International Development (AusAID), which is Nauru’s largest bilateral 
development partner. Ongoing dialogue with the government, the Pacific Financial Technical 
Assistance Center (PFTAC), and the Pacific Infrastructure Advisory Center (PIAC),12 has been 
central to the preparation of the program. ADB is providing TA to the government in the areas 
of  PEFA,  PFM  action  plan,  and  more  rigorous  corporate  governance  for  NUA  and 
RONPHOS.13 PIAC  provided  assistance  to  formulate  the  Nauru  Economic  Infrastructure 
Strategy and Investment Plan. AusAID provides assistance through resident advisors and TA in 
the  areas  of  (i)  financial  management  information  system  (FMIS),  (ii)  revenue  policy  and 
administration, and (iii) reforms in the education and health sectors. PFTAC supports reforms 
of financial instructions and the preparation of balance of payments and national accounts 
statistics. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The impact will be higher living standards of the population of Nauru. The outcome will 
be the delivery of improved equitable social services by the government. Better social service 
delivery  will  lead  to  better  health  and  education  outcomes,  which  will  promote  greater 
participation of Nauruans in income-generating activities both domestically and abroad. The 
program will be structured in two tranches with two sets of policy actions to be accomplished by 
the end of July 2012 and the end of August 2013, respectively. All of the 12 policy actions, 5 of 
which are triggers for the first tranche release, have been completed.

C.  Outputs 
17.  The program will have three outputs: (i) stronger public financial management, (ii) more 
rigorous  corporate  governance  and  economic  performance  of  selected  SOEs,  and  (iii) a 
comprehensive legal and policy framework for equitable access to social services. These 
outputs will improve the delivery of social services by increasing the resources available for 
them as well as improving the equity and efficiency of their use.  
 
18.  Output 1: Stronger public financial management by the Ministry of Finance. The 
program will rectify weaknesses specified in the 2011 PEFA assessment for Nauru.14 Policy 
actions under output 1 are in accordance with the government’s PFM action plan and include 
(i) revenue management, (ii) budget and planning processes, and (iii) overall financial and 
official development assistance management.  
 
19.  Revenue management. The 2011 PFM action plan recommended (i) the establishment 
of a national revenue office to improve revenue collection and administration, and (ii) the 
broadening of the tax base. Under tranche 1, a revenue office was established in September 
2011. For tranche 2, the government will adopt a new taxation policy framework including 
measures to broaden the tax base.  
 
20.  Budget and planning processes. A key recommendation of the PFM action plan, 
developed under ADB regional TA (footnote 8), is the replacement of the current financial 
management system (based on paper and Excel spreadsheets) with a full electronic FMIS 
(computerized accounting system). Under tranche 1, the government established the FMIS with 
assistance from AusAID in September 2011. The FMIS—Technology One Financials—will 
ensure stronger financial management and accounting capability. The system will reduce both 
the amount of paperwork and time required for the budget and expenditure approvals. In 
addition, all expenditure commitments and actual payments can be simultaneously taken into 
account when the assessment is done. If a particular line item has low payments against it but 
has  high  commitments  that  result  in  insufficient  budget  being  available  for  a  proposed 
purchase, the system will not allow the purchase requisition to be processed. This greatly 
reduces the risk of overspending against the approved budget. The FMIS has four modules: (i) 
general ledger, (ii) accounts payable, (iii) accounts receivable, and (iv) purchasing. Since the 
FMIS went live on 7 September 2011, progress has been steady. The FMIS was initially 
introduced in the finance, education, and health ministries, and the Chief Justice’s Department.  
 
21.  Senior  government  officials  will  develop  awareness  and  understanding  of  gender-
responsive  budgeting  processes  and  requirements.  This  will  improve  equitable  budget 
allocations and expenditures. As part of tranche 2, all members of the National Development 
Committee will be accustomed to gender-sensitive budgeting through tabling and discussion of 
an issues paper at meetings of the committee. Such heightened awareness will complement 
gender-related reforms to legal and policy frameworks and increase the likelihood of their 
effective implementation. 
 
22.  Under  tranche  1,  the  government  adopted  the  National  Economic  Infrastructure 
Strategy and Investment Plan in February 2012, which was developed with the assistance of 
PIAC, and will implement this plan under tranche 2. 
 
                                                 
14 ADB. 2011. Nauru: Public Financial Management Performance Report. Consultant’s report. Manila (TA 6507-
REG).

5 
23.  Under tranche 1, the program supported the publication of historical national accounts 
and balance of payments statistics for 2004–2009 in February 2012. Under tranche 2, the 
program includes (i) the publication of national accounts and balance of payments data for 
2010–2011, and (ii) the conduct of a census and a household income and expenditure survey. 
 
24.  Overall  financial  and  aid  management. PFTAC drafted a revised  set of financial 
instructions, incorporating more effective internal controls. Under tranche 2, the program will 
support the further development and adoption of these instructions taking into account changes 
from the introduction of the FMIS.  
 
25.  The government developed and approved a new procurement policy under tranche 1 in 
May 2012. This new policy and guidelines will require the centralization and outsourcing of all 
government and SOE procurement above A$5,000 to an independent, external agency. Under 
tranche  2,  the  government  will  implement  the  new  procurement  policy  and  guidelines  by 
contracting an external procurement agency. Dedicated Nauruan officials will be appointed to 
work with the external agency and at the warehouse. AusAID will provide capacity development 
TA to assist the government in adequately overseeing the performance of the external agency 
in FY2013.15 
 
26.  The  government  is  also  accelerating  the  outsourcing  of  the  bulk  procurement  of 
petroleum for the country. Potential benefits of this arrangement include (i) cost savings and 
additional revenues for the national budget, (ii) better security and quality of fuel supply, and 
(iii) competitive prices for the local market. Prior to entering into such an arrangement, the 
government will conduct a detailed cost–benefit analysis in which ADB will participate. 
 
27.  An updated debt strategy, developed with the assistance of ADB regional TA, provides 
revised debt figures and recommendations for the government on managing internal debt. This 
includes the liquidation of the Bank of Nauru, which accounts for 90% of internal debt. Under 
tranche 1, the government adopted an updated debt management strategy in February 2012. 
Under tranche 2, the government will advance the liquidation of the Bank of Nauru through 
agreement of a settlement with depositors.  
 
28.  Output 2: More rigorous corporate governance and economic performance of 
selected  state-owned  enterprises.  The  program  will  support  the  government’s  effort  to 
improve the corporate governance and performance of two key SOEs—NUA and RONPHOS—
assisted  by  ADB  TA  (footnote  13).  The  program  will  support  the  corporatization  and 
commercialization of NUA to improve its corporate governance and economic performance. 
Under tranche 1, NUA was corporatized through the passage of an act establishing the Nauru 
Utilities  Corporation  (NUC)  in  July  2011.  Under  tranche  2,  NUC  will  be  gradually 
commercialized through the use of performance-based contracts for senior management.  
 
29.   A  recent  review 16  recommended  the  following  actions  to  improve  RONPHOS’s 
performance:  (i)  a  new  corporate  structure  with  an  executive  team  comprising  the  chief 
executive officer, an operations manager, and a corporate manager; and (ii) legislative changes 
to separate governance from management. Under tranche 1, a chief executive officer was 
recruited  to  focus  on  strategic  issues  in  September  2011,  including  the  preparation  of  a 
business plan and the implementation of a performance management system. Under tranche 2,

the RONPHOS Act will be amended to better separate governance from management.  
 
30.  Women have generally been underrepresented on SOE boards that provide essential 
services and generate much of the country’s income. Under tranche 2, the government will 
appoint at least one qualified woman each to the majority of SOE boards. 
 
31.  Output  3:  Enhanced  legal  and  policy  framework  for  equitable  social  service 
delivery. Equitable social service delivery will be improved through (i) a new education act 
requiring compulsory secondary education for males and females; (ii) an education re-entry 
program including support for single mothers; (iii) adoption of detailed sector strategies for 
health and education; and (iv) adoption of a national women’s policy and CEDAW plan of 
action.  
 
32.  Under tranche 1, detailed sector strategies were introduced for health and education by 
July 2011, which include numerical targets for enrollments, completion rates, infant mortality 
rates, and maternal health. This has already begun to pay dividends in improving education 
service delivery. 
 
33.  Nauruan  women,  like  their  male  counterparts,  have  low  secondary  education 
completion rates (less than 20%). This limits access to jobs in Nauru and abroad. Under 
tranche 1, the Parliament passed the Education Act in July 2011, which makes primary and 
secondary education compulsory for children aged 6–18 years. For tranche 2, the government 
is preparing a re-entry program for school dropouts that will enable single mothers to re-enter 
the education system.   
 
34.  The Constitution gives equal rights to women and men. Under tranche 1, Nauru ratified 
CEDAW in June 2011. For tranche 2, the government is preparing a legal review for CEDAW 
compliance, with a plan to finalize the review report in 2013. A national women’s policy and 
CEDAW implementation plan of action are also under preparation for tranche 2 by the Ministry 
of Home Affairs and are expected to be adopted by August 2013.  
 
D.  Development Financing Needs 
 
35.  The government requested a grant not exceeding $4.0 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds resources to help finance the program. The grant size was determined based on the 
adjustment  costs  for  the  proposed  reforms,  which  include  implementation  of  the  FMIS, 
outsourcing government procurement, more spending on health and education under new 
sector  strategies,  establishment  of  a  revenue  office,  cost  of  corporatizing  NUA,  and 
establishment of a performance management system for key SOEs. The government has 
specified that a portion of the tranche 2 grant proceeds may be put aside to fund future social 
service delivery. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
36.  The program will be implemented over 34 months, from June 2011 to April 2014, with 
post-program monitoring continuing to September 2014. Nauru is classified as at high risk of 
debt distress and is therefore eligible to receive 100% grant assistance. The grant will be 
provided  in  two  tranches.  The  first  tranche  of  $2  million  will  be  available  upon  grant 
effectiveness as all the policy actions for the first tranche have been accomplished. The second 
tranche of $2 million will be available upon as the government accomplishes the policy actions 
for the second  tranche, projected to be achieved by August 2013.

7 
37.  The proceeds of the grant will be disbursed to Nauru as the recipient according to 
ADB’s  simplified  disbursement  procedures.17 The  proceeds  will  be  used  to  finance  items 
produced and procured in ADB member countries; items in the list of ineligible items and 
imports financed by other bilateral and multilateral sources are excluded.18 Grant proceeds 
disbursed against imports will require a certificate from the government stipulating that the 
value of the total imports of Nauru, minus its imports from nonmember countries, ineligible 
imports, and imports financed under other official development assistance, is greater than the 
amount of the grant to be disbursed during a particular year. Local currency generated from the 
proceeds of the grants will be used to support public expenditure objectives under the program. 
 
38.  The Ministry of Finance (MOF) will be the executing agency and will oversee policy, 
legal, and regulatory actions and ensure that the agreed policy actions are duly carried out. The 
MOF will also be responsible for the overall implementation of the program, including carrying 
out all policy actions, program administration, disbursements, and maintenance of all program 
records. The MOF will (i) establish and maintain a performance evaluation system for the 
program, which will be derived from the design and monitoring framework, policy letter, and 
policy matrix; and (ii) monitor and report to ADB, on an semiannual basis over the term of the 
program, the implementation of policy actions and their impact on program outcome, in line 
with the program impact and outcome indicators agreed upon. Specific policy actions will also 
be implemented by the NUC, RONPHOS, the Ministry of Health and Medical Services, the 
Ministry of Education, and the Ministry of Home Affairs.  
 
39.  The  government  will  continue  to  keep  ADB  informed  of  the  outcome  of  policy 
discussions with other multilateral and bilateral agencies that have implications for program 
implementation, and will provide ADB with the opportunity to comment on any resulting policy 
proposals.  ADB,  in  collaboration  with  MOF  and  key  development  partners,  will  undertake 
regular reviews of program performance. The reviews will evaluate implementation of the policy 
reform measures and assess the impact, describe lessons learned during the program period, 
and outline policy actions and any assistance needed for sustained and inclusive economic 
growth. The program design has drawn on dialogue with civil society, such as the Nauru 
Private  Business  Sector  Organization  and  Nauru  Island  Association  of  Nongovernment 
Organizations. During implementation, ADB will continue consultation with civil society.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Economic and Financial 
40.  Short- and medium-term growth prospects depend on developments in the phosphate 
industry.  Since  the  resumption  of  phosphate  exports  in  2007,19 phosphate  mining  and 
processing (included in manufacturing) has regained its prominence in the Nauru economy and 
in FY2009, accounted for almost 40% of gross domestic product. Primary phosphate reserves 
are estimated to be enough for 1–2 years of production, and deeper, secondary reserves are 
expected to last 20 years. Some increase in phosphate exports is now taking place; phosphate 
exports of 385,000 tons were achieved for FY2011 compared with 17,200 tons in FY2006, the 
first year after the resumption of phosphate exports, and 319,000 tons in FY2010. The world 
phosphate rock market has improved after declining in FY2009. The long-term outlook is 
favorable at present and demand is expected to continue to grow at an average rate of around 
3% per annum during the 10-year period 2011–2020. Recently improved phosphate-loading 
facilities and stronger management of RONPHOS are expected to lift phosphate exports to 
over 500,000 tons in FY2012, taking economic growth to 4.8% in FY2012 and 4.2% in FY2013. 
 
B.  Governance 
41.  Public financial management. The quality of PFM has improved in recent years. The 
government’s  recent  major  reform  initiative  has  been  the  adoption and  maintenance  of a 
prudent fiscal management strategy, first initiated in 2004. The government’s conservative 
fiscal strategy has ended a long period of fiscal mismanagement and stabilized its financial 
position.  This  strategy  has  included  achieving  a  balanced  budget,  directing  government 
expenditure to the provision of basic services, starting to widen the government’s revenue 
base, stabilizing its very high debt position through debt write-offs and negotiated settlements 
with creditors, and reducing the size of the public service and the value of subsidies provided to 
public enterprises. Donors have contributed a high level of TA in several PFM areas since 2008 
due to weak capacity levels within the government. Weaknesses remain, however, in public 
sector financial management, which are adversely affecting public service delivery, threatening 
aggregate fiscal discipline, and undermining the strategic allocation of public resources. The 
limited  medium-term  focus  in  budgeting,  weak  internal  control  systems  (especially  in 
procurement and internal audit), and low accounting standards represent major constraints to 
the delivery of basic services. The absence of government financial statements has prevented 
stakeholder scrutiny that would normally assist the review of sector budgetary allocations and 
service delivery performance levels. The government has prepared a PFM action plan following 
on from the PEFA assessment in 2011. 
 
42.  Anticorruption efforts. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was 
explained  to  and  discussed  with  the  government  and  MOF  and  forms  part  of  the  legal 
documents.  Consistent  with  its  commitment  to  good  governance,  accountability,  and 
transparency, ADB reserves the right to investigate, directly or through its agents, any alleged 
corrupt, fraudulent, collusive, or coercive practices relating to the program. These measures 
will  complement  anticorruption  measures  and  actions  under  way  to  improve  financial 
accountability.  Key  actions  relate  to  the  revision  of  financial  management  systems,  the 
refinement of financial instructions and the improvement of procurement practices. 
                                                 
19  Phosphate exports had ceased in the early 2000s due to poor infrastructure and lack of demand but resumed in 
2007 following an agreement between Nauru and the Australian fertilizer company, Incitec Pivot, to refurbish the 
facility.

9 
 
C.  Poverty and Social 
43.  The program will contribute to poverty reduction and social development through the 
following  key  program  components.  More  rigorous  corporate  governance  and  economic 
performance  of  SOEs  will  lead  to  (i)  more  phosphate  revenues,  which  will  provide  more 
resources for social service delivery and poverty reduction; (ii) reduced transfers of scarce 
public  resources  to  SOEs,  which  will  free  revenues  for  use  in  more  activities  related  to 
development and poverty reduction; and (iii) more efficient and equitable service delivery from 
NUC. Stronger PFM will lead to (i) better value for money in procurement, which will free up 
more government resources; (ii) strengthened tax administration, which will increase revenue 
available to the government for social service delivery; (iii) better tracking and accountability of 
government funds through a new FMIS; and (iv) reduced debt burden on the country through a 
debt management strategy and liquidation of the Bank of Nauru. 
 
44.  The program is anchored to the National Sustainable Development Strategy, which the 
government developed through a consultative process. Priority services to be supported under 
the program are derived from consultation with the ministries of commerce, industries, and 
environment; education; finance; health; and home affairs and reflect their respective priorities 
and budget positions.  
 
45.  There will also be economic empowerment of women through greater representation on 
SOE boards and greater awareness of gender-sensitive budget issues. Social service delivery 
will be made more equitable through (i) the Education Act that requires compulsory secondary 
education for males and females; (ii) an education re-entry program that includes support for 
single mothers; (iii) implementation of detailed sector strategies for health and education that 
include numerical targets for enrollments, completion rates, infant mortality rates, and maternal 
health; and (iv) adoption of a national women’s policy and CEDAW plan of action.   
 
D.  Safeguards 
46.  Program activities will be confined to policy and institutional reforms and none of the 
activities will result in or lead to involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples issues. Thus, 
the program is category C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. 
No adverse environmental impacts have been identified. Public consultation was carried out 
during program preparation.  
 
E.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
47.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 2 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.20 Key risks in the program revolve around 
weak  local  capacity  and  political  instability.  This  grant  has  been  developed  under  three 
separate governments in Nauru. ADB has maintained a high level of consultation with the 
government, the opposition, and other stakeholders during processing and this will continue to 
be a feature of the grant during implementation.

IV.  ASSURANCES  
48.  The government and MOF have assured ADB that implementation of the program will 
conform with all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the grant documents. The government and MOF have agreed with ADB on certain covenants 
for the program, which are set forth in the grant agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
49.  I am satisfied that the proposed policy-based grant would comply with the Articles of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
grant not exceeding $4,000,000 to Nauru from ADB’s Special Funds resources for the Public 
Financial Management Reform Program, on terms and conditions that are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft grant agreement presented to the Board.
